meanings.definition: To burst open or split apart
meanings.sent1: The ripe fruit will dehisce when it falls from the tree.
meanings.sent2: The old balloon started to dehisce, making a loud popping sound.
meanings.sent3: As the pressure built up, the balloon had no choice but to dehisce dramatically.
meanings.sent4: The dam finally dehisced under the force of the floodwaters.
meanings.sent5: The volcano seemed to dehisce with a mighty roar, spewing lava into the sky.

meanings.definition: To release seeds or spores through a natural opening
meanings.sent1: The plant will dehisce its seeds when they are fully mature.
meanings.sent2: In the autumn, the pods dehisce, scattering seeds across the forest floor.
meanings.sent3: The flower seemed to dehisce its pollen in a playful dance with the wind.
meanings.sent4: The pine cone dehisced, spreading its seeds far and wide.
meanings.sent5: The dandelion dehisced its fluffy seeds, carried away by the breeze.

meanings.definition: To open up or separate along a line of weakness
meanings.sent1: The wound began to dehisce, causing concern for infection.
meanings.sent2: Over time, the fabric of the old tent started to dehisce along the seams.
meanings.sent3: The overstuffed suitcase dehisced at the zipper, spilling clothes everywhere.
meanings.sent4: The crack in the wall slowly dehisced, revealing a hidden chamber.
meanings.sent5: The ice on the lake began to dehisce, creating a dangerous situation for skaters.
